According to Newton's second law, the acceleration of an object is given by F = ma.
F is the net force acting on the object, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration of the object.
The net force acting on the small ball is the force of gravity, which is mg.
The acceleration of the small ball is the same as the acceleration due to gravity, which is g.
The acceleration of the small ball is constant, and the acceleration due to gravity is constant.
According to Newton's second law, the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to its mass and inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the center of gravity.
The distance from the center of gravity to the point where the small ball is thrown is half the distance between the point light source and the right wall.
The acceleration of the small ball is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the center of gravity to the point where the small ball is thrown.
